title: Methods (What Your Objects Can Do)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine a TV remote. Each button makes the TV DO something: change channel, adjust volume, power on/off. You don't know HOW it works inside - you just press the button!

METHODS are like those buttons - they make objects DO things. Properties hold data (what the object IS), methods define behavior (what the object CAN DO).

Methods can:
• Take INPUT (parameters) - 'Add these two numbers'
• Produce OUTPUT (return value) - 'Here's the result: 7'
• Modify the object's state - 'Increase my score by 10'
• Just perform actions (void) - 'Print this message'

Think: A Calculator object has Add(), Subtract(), Multiply() methods. A Player object has TakeDamage(), Heal(), Attack() methods. Methods bring objects to LIFE!

syntaxBreakdown.codeSnippet: public int Add(int a, int b)
syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Method signature: access modifier (public), return type (int), name (Add), parameters (int a, int b). This method takes two ints and returns an int.
The 'return' keyword sends a value back to the caller. The type MUST match the method's return type (int here). return exits the method immediately!
'void' means 'returns nothing'. Use void for methods that DO something but don't need to send a value back. No return statement needed (or use 'return;' to exit early).
You can have multiple methods with the SAME NAME but DIFFERENT parameters: Add(int, int), Add(double, double), Add(int, int, int). C# picks the right one based on arguments!

challenge.instructions:
Create a Game character class with action methods!

1. Class 'Character' with fields: string Name, int Health = 100, int Mana = 50
2. Method 'Attack' (returns int): returns random damage 10-20
3. Method 'Heal' (void, takes int amount): adds amount to Health (max 100)
4. Method 'CastSpell' (returns bool): if Mana >= 20, reduce Mana by 20 and return true, else return false
5. Create a character and call all methods, display results
challenge.hint: Method structure: public ReturnType MethodName(parameters) { code; return value; }. Use void for no return. Methods can access and modify the object's fields!
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting 'return': If method returns a value (not void), you MUST return something! 'public int Add(int a, int b) { a + b; }' is WRONG - needs 'return a + b;'
Calling methods without parentheses: player.Attack is WRONG! Must be player.Attack() - parentheses are REQUIRED even with no parameters!
Wrong return type: If method returns int, you can't return a string! The return value type MUST match the method signature.
Not storing return values: int result = calc.Add(5, 3); stores the result. calc.Add(5, 3); without storing throws away the return value!
